conversation:
Raphael: There. Middle-of-somewhere.
Karlach: I don't like this at all.
Player: Can you be more specific than 'somewhere'?
Raphael: The House of Hope. Where the tired come to rest, and the famished come to feed - lavishly.
NodeContext: He spreads his arms as he dramatically introduces this place.
Raphael: Go on. Partake. Enjoy your supper. After all...
Raphael: ...it might just be your last.
Player: What makes you say that?
Raphael: Call it a ninth sense.
Raphael: What's better than a devil you don't know?
Raphael: A devil you do.
Wyll: Hollering hells - you're a cambion.
Raphael: And so much more.
Raphael: Am I a friend? Potentially. An adversary? Conceivably. But a saviour? That's for certain.
Player: Level your weapon at the creature.
Raphael: My, aren't you a nervous one! I assure you I'm here to help, not harm.
Raphael: Consider your predicament.
Raphael: One skull, two tenants, and no solution in sight.
Raphael: I could fix it all like that.
NodeContext: He snaps his fingers on the word 'that'. As he does so, the candle flames suddenly shine unnaturally bright, bathing the scene in a hellish red glow.
Player: I'll do anything to get rid of the tadpole.

Raphael: There. Middle-of-somewhere.
Karlach: I don't like this at all.
Player: Take me back. Now.
Raphael: And deny you the honour of my hospitality?
Raphael: This is the House of Hope. Where the tired come to rest, and the famished come to feed - lavishly.
Raphael: Go on. Partake. Enjoy your supper. After all...
Raphael: ...it might just be your last.
Player: I'm getting tired of your games.
Raphael: Fair enough.
Raphael: What's better than a devil you don't know?
Raphael: A devil you do.
Wyll: Hollering hells - you're a cambion.
Raphael: And so much more.
Raphael: Am I a friend? Potentially. An adversary? Conceivably. But a saviour? That's for certain.
Player: Why would you help me?
Raphael: Because my compassion is boundless. I stride among the needy, giving comfort where I can.
Raphael: And you're in dire need. One skull, two tenants, and no solution in sight.
Raphael: I could fix it all like that.
NodeContext: He snaps his fingers on the word 'that'. As he does so, the candle flames suddenly shine unnaturally bright, bathing the scene in a hellish red glow.
Player: I'll do anything to get rid of the tadpole.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is already in her room.
InternalNodeContext: The ritual was disturbed and Isobel is already in the room (dialogue was interrupted, someone yanked her into the room, etc.)
InternalNodeContext: The ritual was disturbed and Isobel is already in the room (dialogue was interrupted, someone yanked her into the room, etc.)
Isobel: You're here for the protection spell, right? Come on - let's get you fit for purpose.
Narrator: *Pain bursts from the wound on your hand. You see yourself kneeling in a dark hall, surrounded by initiates. A female voice preaches against Selûne and all she stands for. You nod, rapt.*
InternalNodeContext: Incurable wound imagery/memoriy fragment
Isobel: Well! If the Moonmaiden didn't strike me dead for blessing you, she must rather approve of this little alliance.
Isobel: This will block the lesser effects of the shadow curse, allowing you to traverse the darkness outside... should Shar's own protection falter, that is.
Isobel: It won't be enough to protect you against areas of utter darkness, though - where the curse is strongest. This lantern should, though.
Player: I already have a Moonlantern. I can safely travel the shadows.
Isobel: Well! Now you have two. Just in case.
Isobel: I wish you luck. The very best of it.
Player: Wait - Marcus is a True Soul, you know. And not the good kind, like me.

GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Wait! Argh. Wait just a tick.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Killing me is a waste of time - I'll find a way to return. Always have, always will.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: But it's... unpleasant. So how about we be civilised about this, hmm? I have something you want.
Player: Careful. I doubt we have the same concept of 'civilised'.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: Hold your horses - just hear me out.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: I can give you power. Anything you want!
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: You want to be stronger? Tougher? Smarter? Done! Just let me go. (Ability Score +1)
Karlach: Poisoned deal. Trust me. Don't believe a word she says.
GROUP_Act1_GLO_HagHag: What'll it be, petal?
Player: Keep your life and your magic. I don't want either.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: Hide Marcus
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Isobel is standing on the balcony, bathed in a beam of moonlight piercing the darkness. Her hands are in a prayer position and she's chanting softly as the moonlight dances around her. She exhales, then inhales and breaths in tendrils of shadow, absorbing them. She swallows, then begins hacking coughing. The moonlight dissipates. She quickly goes from seeming like a divine spirit to a normal young woman.
Isobel: I didn't realise I had an audience.
Fist Marcus: Isobel. This is -
Isobel: The True Soul who's going to save us all. Pleased to meet you.
Narrator: *The Urge deep within tingles. This is the one the Butler commanded you to kill.*
Player: Push your Urges down.
Narrator: *You choke down the obscene thoughts racking your body with a shiver.*
Player: And you. I've heard you're the protector of this inn - the banisher of shadows.
Isobel: Myself and our Lady are doing what we can to hold the line. I hear you and your tadpole will be our offence.
Isobel: Free from the Absolute's influence, yet able to walk among cultists.
Isobel: It's almost too good to be true. But I'd be a poor cleric indeed not to avail of a blessing when I see one.
Isobel: Let me guess: Jaheira's sent you to beg a protection spell off her favourite cleric.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I thought I made myself very clear, civilian. Move along.
Player: You're going to want to see this. Show her the murder target list.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right!
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll tell you what I know.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: Not only is the cult back, it's spreading fast. I ran into some Bhaalists in the park.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: No doubt you found a trail of bodies in their wake?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I've got better things to do than investigate a cult.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I suppose it was quite an ask... but perhaps you wouldn't mind doing me a different, smaller favour?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: You're supposed to keep the peace, not stoke the fire.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: What peace? If no one steps in, there'll be bodies piled high in the streets before long.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: I will do better than mindless slaughter: it is not the answer.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I thought I made myself very clear, civilian. Move along.
Player: Recount your investigation into Father Lorgan's murder, and show her the list you found.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right!
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll tell you what I know.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. This list you brought me confirms I'm right.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: What makes you think it's not Sarevok himself?
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've not ruled out the possibility that it is Sarevok himself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The brutality of the killings is certainly reminiscent of his work. But there's something more here, something new...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Follow the trail of these murders. Prove the truth. Use your lineage to get places the Fist can't.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.

Madeline: You didn't see it. Didn't see what the Dark Justiciar did.
Madeline: She gave 'em a dagger each, and told 'em to press it against their stomachs.
Madeline: On the count of three, to 'start stabbin', and not to stop 'til she said so.
Madeline: She never said stop. I'd do anything to take it back. Anything.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: It is. I can't believe I'm finally here.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Well, whatever you've heard - the reality might not be quite so rosy.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: I've got ways of making people share.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: The way things are going, it might well come to that.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: You're supposed to keep the peace, not stoke the fire.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: What peace? If no one steps in, there'll be bodies piled high in the streets before long.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: Let's soak the earth with entrails, kill and kill again!

Orin: Loosen the bonds, sweet meat. Bhaal does not crave the taste of bait on his altar.
NodeContext: Mocking the player  for saving their companion - it was never about them
Orin: No trust in my promises, but I smell the tyrant's corpse-reek. You are steeped in his rot.
Orin: See how good I was? How patient while you drained the tyrant's juices for me?
Orin: I left the blood inside, the pelt unskinned. But I had such plans for this one, and the blade was made to slice...
NodeContext: Longing, playful - on the cusp of unleashhing her violence. All refering to the victim on the slab, but speaking to the player
Player: Harm her and I swear I'll do tenfold worse to you.
Orin: Is your skull thick with thoughts about your blade in my belly? Cutting and cutting and cutting.
Orin: Shred me. Tear me. It is Bhaal's blood you spill from my flesh. And you might, now the tyrant rots.
NodeContext: Likes the idea of her own pain as much as causing someone else's. Setting her sights on the player now. 'Tyrant' is Gortash.
Orin: All the lordling's pretty plans, bleeding out in the gutters. And soon your crimson will join his.
Orin: I will finish what my grandfather started. Sarevok brought this city to its knees, but I will be the one to slit its throat. I am Bhaal's Chosen.
Player: Baldur's Gate deserves such a fate. Your vision is exquisite.

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Well? Have you found anything?
Player: Recount your investigation into Father Lorgan's murder, and show her the list you found.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right!
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll tell you what I know.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. This list you brought me confirms I'm right.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: You're absolutely right. I have reasons of my own to think there's been an increase in Bhaalist activity.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Good. Then your eyes are open to the truth.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've done everything I can within the remit of my job. Any more, and they'll fire me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.

Mol: Little slow on the uptake, aren't you?

Mol: Maybe we can do something about this.

Oskar Fevras: Oh, thank the gods - if it's wealth you seek then you've done yourself a great service, friend.
Oskar Fevras: For you've rescued none other than the artist Oskar Fevras.
Oskar Fevras: Well, you should at least know what you've paid for. I am the Oskar Fevras, at your service.
Player: And I am [GEN_PlayerName_c11eee1e-7815-6143-7233-f2427799fa53].
Oskar Fevras: A genuine pleasure. I'm in your debt - as is my patron. My betrothed, I should say.
Oskar Fevras: Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
Player: Who is Lady Jannath?
Oskar Fevras: A noblewoman of passion, refinement and, as it turns out, quite ferocious temper.
Oskar Fevras: The latter I learned only after the engagement, when I told her I was in love with someone else.
Oskar Fevras: I made a timely retreat into the countryside. To paint, and clear my head. To choose, I suppose.
Player: I saw your paintings - were they portraits of the women you spoke of?
Oskar Fevras: Indeed. I thought the canvas would make clear what my heart could not.
Oskar Fevras: Both turned out masterpieces, more's the pity. Not a stray brushstroke between them.
Oskar Fevras: They're yours, if you can find use for them - in the privy perhaps. I had best get moving.
Oskar Fevras: Say - I don't suppose you could spare some coin, could you? Ease the discomforts of the road some?
Player: I can spare a little. ([GEN_CheckMagicPocketGold_6057ad05-9492-4630-9f0a-be548b134c54])

Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I thought I made myself very clear, civilian. Move along.
Player: You're going to want to see this. Show her the murder target list.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods... This is it. The proof that I was right!
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I've been working on an assignment, see - a research project of sorts. I knew my conclusions were sound, but this... I never expected this.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll tell you what I know.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: A century ago, there was a man - Sarevok Anchev. He was a child of the god of murder, Bhaal.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: He ruled the Iron Throne - a dark tower hiding a darker secret. It was the front for a deadly arms-dealing network.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There, Sarevok amassed an army and sought to become a god. Under his stewardship, the Bhaal Temple was revived, and with it, the Bhaal cult itself.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Fortunately, the Temple was destroyed, and to cleanse the city of Sarevok's memory, the Iron Throne was torn from its foundations and cast into the Chionthar.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: For most, that was the end of it. But cults like that don't disappear overnight. That list you spoke of confirms I'm right.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The Bhaal cult is back, and someone is out there, continuing Sarevok's work.
Player: I think it may be a Bhaalspawn...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: Gods save us all if you're right, but I'd believe it. Whoever it is, they are intimately familiar with Sarevok's work.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The brutality of the killings is on a par with Sarevok's own. But there's something more here, something new...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There's a reverence to these murders, a certain flair. It's as if they were done in worship.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: The precision of the cuts, the depth, the execution - the best butchers in Faerûn couldn't make a cut like that. Trust me, I've asked them.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I tried to explain all this to my superiors, but they wouldn't have any of it.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: They told me to drop it. Told me the city doesn't need another conspiracy theorist and to get back to doing my job before they find someone else to do it for me.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: But you - you're not bound by such constraints. Help me out, here. Help the city out.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: I'll bet if you follow the trail of these murders, you'll be able to unearth the truth of this resurgence.
Player: I'll do my best.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: You really are a godsend. But - one more thing...
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: There are patriars on the murder target list. I'm oathbound to secure them first, so I'll be heading to the Upper City next.
Gauntlet Devella Fountainhead: While I'm there, the other potential victims will be at risk. Could you warn them?
Player: I'll see what I can do.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it?
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Forgive me - you're in no mood to talk about the weather. Your journey here was a hard one, no doubt.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Is this your first time in Baldur's Gate?
Player: I've passed through, but I'm a Waterdeep man at heart.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: A word of advice then - you might not get as warm a welcome as in days gone by.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Used to be you'd arrive knowing you'd a full belly and a warm bed waiting for you. Not any more.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: These days, there's barely enough to go around. Add the refugees on top and... well, folk aren't feeling too generous.
Player: I didn't come looking for handouts. I take care of myself.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: That might be the simplest approach. Unfortunately, not everyone sees things that way.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Some well-to-do's in the city donated enough to see the newcomers right for the time being. Only they didn't bother helping everyone else.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Locals going without while strangers feast - it's stoked the fire, all right. Some Baldurians are kicking up a fuss round the front of the barn as we speak.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: If I wasn't wearing this uniform, I'd walk round there and teach them a lesson they'd never forget.
Player: If the refugees have more than they need, it's only fair they give some back.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Too bloody right. But will they share? Not a chance.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Those refugees have been leeching on our city for too long. If we don't show them we mean business, they'll bleed us dry.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: We need to march round the front, and kill every last one of them. Let's see them eat our food with their guts on the floor. What do you say?
Player: I kill discreetly and with purpose. Openly slaughtering civilians is hardly my chosen approach.

Nightwarden Minthara: I will never tire of sitting on dead men's thrones.
Player: And I'll never tire of killing their previous occupants. We make a good team.
Nightwarden Minthara: We make an acceptable team. But there are greater challenges than Ketheric ahead of us.
Nightwarden Minthara: It is clear, now, that he was not working alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: So it's personal? Good - let's take her down.
Nightwarden Minthara: You make it sound so simple. She is the Chosen of Bhaal, Lord of Murder, and one of the cult's founders.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.
Nightwarden Minthara: If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: We'll be heroes - the saviours of Baldur's Gate.
Nightwarden Minthara: Let them think that. There is a short path from saviour to ruler - a short and bloody path. I know it well, and we will walk it together.
Nightwarden Minthara: But Baldur's Gate is a mere bauble. We have the chance to seize something much greater. Surely you see it?
Nightwarden Minthara: In killing Ketheric, we fractured the cult's leadership. When we break the other Chosen and claim their Netherstones, we can take control.
Player: Madness. We need to eradicate the cult and the elder brain.

[description] CinematicNodeContext: shot of player and whatever remaining gnomes are alive panting, catching their breath. Wulbren appears and claps slowly
Wulbren Bongle: That was a hell of a show, my friend. Watchers collapse in the street as we speak, and the Foundry?
Wulbren Bongle: The scent of runepowder drifts through the city like a warm embrace - I see my bomb did the trick.
Wulbren Bongle: Watchers collapse in the street as we speak. The city thanks you - I thank you.
Wulbren Bongle: But it's not over - so long as a single parasitic Gondian remains, Baldur's Gate is under threat.

Gondian Zanner Toobin: Take the city - let the Ironhands reign supreme. I just wish to go home, and to hold my daughter.

("safe houses" as in "safehouses" for shelter)
Wulbren Bongle: Please - if a Gondian told me the sky was blue, I'd look outside and check.
Wulbren Bongle: Toobin will lie, torment, and scheme until his dying breath. Kill him - or the Ironhands will.
Wulbren Bongle: You Gondians will lie, scheme, and torment this city until your dying breaths. Let's end this.

Oskar Fevras: Wait, WAIT! I'm just a prisoner - spare me and there'll be coin, I swear it!

Player: You're not a prisoner anymore.

Oskar Fevras: For you've rescued none other than the artist Oskar Fevras.
Oskar Fevras: Well, you should at least know what you've paid for. I am the Oskar Fevras, at your service.
Player: What will you do with your freedom?
Oskar Fevras: Oh - run crying back to my patron I expect. My betrothed, I should say.
Oskar Fevras: A genuine pleasure. I'm in your debt - as is my patron. My betrothed, I should say.
Oskar Fevras: Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
: True
Narrator: *You recall a recent scandal - a patriar of Baldur's Gate who wished to marry a commoner.*
Oskar Fevras: Assuming Lady Jannath still wishes to marry after our little... falling out.
Player: What happened?
Oskar Fevras: She offered me a future, and so in a fit of madness I told her of my past.
Oskar Fevras: Of the woman I'd loved before she found me. Love still, in truth. She was... less than pleased.
Oskar Fevras: I made a timely retreat into the countryside. To paint, and clear my head. To choose, I suppose.

Lord Enver Gortash: You have the Netherstones - they resonate with my own.
Lord Enver Gortash: I commend you for putting an end to Orin's madness - she must be screaming bloody murder in the Hells even now.

Lord Enver Gortash: I see murder as a grim necessity, to provoke a desired response from those who witness it. To Orin, it was a pleasurable pastime.
Lord Enver Gortash: I don't even want to know what it is to you.
Lord Enver Gortash: My involvement with Orin was never a true alliance. A mad dog understands the yank of the leash and the hand of its master, but it cannot be an equal.
Lord Enver Gortash: You can be my equal.
Lord Enver Gortash: We will raise a Black Keep in Baldur's Gate. Then we will conquer the Sword Coast, and unite all its peoples under our rule. But first -

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_FlamingFist: Hail, friend. Fine day, isn't it?

Zevlor: You acted quickly. I'm just sorry I didn't get there first.

Zevlor: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.

Player: Enough about the ritual. I have my own problems.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Welcome, adventurer! I take it you're new to Rivington.

Player: Quickly and efficiently. I don't want anyone to suffer.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Come - we're all friends here. No need to pretend you don't like to twist the knife.

Player: Certainty. If I kill, it is because my god demanded it.
GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Killing holds no fear for you, does it? You understand what it takes, and what it gives.

GROUP_Act3_WYR_OrinsImpersonation_Smith: Do you think you could turn your weapon on those closest to you?

Alfira: First cultists nearly murder us, and now we have a traitor on the inside? Can't we trust anyone?
NodeContext: frustrated and tired of being scared

Alfira: Maybe that's why they picked him. Told him to kneel...
Alfira: They took his eyes first. Then his tongue.

Alfira: Which...? Back in the grove, he ran drills with the kids. Wooden swords and the like. That seems like a lifetime ago now.
Alfira: Rolan, of all people, saved us.
Alfira: He said he stayed in the grove because of you, and I'm damn glad of it. Without him... well, none of us would be here.

Alfira: Can you blame him? His brother and sister are gone. He's... dealing with it as best he can. We all are.
Alfira: How do you do it? How do you keep going?

Alfira: You've done so much for us already, but I have to ask - the others might still be out there.
Alfira: If they're not dead, they're in Moonrise. And gods have mercy on anyone in that hellspit.

Nightwarden Minthara: You killed the dead man. I'm impressed.
Nightwarden Minthara: And now your path takes you to Baldur's Gate. I shall walk that path with you.
Player: Excellent - I could have used your help against Ketheric. He was a formidable foe.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed. And now we know that he was not acting alone.
[description] CinematicNodeContext: Leaves throne, standing from here on
Nightwarden Minthara: We must be free if we are to rule - and to be free, we must destroy this cult, and Ketheric's co-conspirators along with it.
Nightwarden Minthara: I know one of them all too well - Bhaal's blood-letter, Orin.
Nightwarden Minthara: To think I thought her to be speaking for the Absolute. I worshipped that woman.
Player: When I murder her, Bhaal will choose me in her place.
Nightwarden Minthara: I would prefer to put my faith in your strength than the favour of your god. After all, it is Orin and this grand deception that he chose - not you.
Nightwarden Minthara: He favours her, and she is one of the founders of this insane cult.
Nightwarden Minthara: Indeed, she is the one who indoctrinated me with the Absolute's lies.
Player: What can you tell me about Orin?
Nightwarden Minthara: She is fierce, vicious, and cruel. In those respects, we are alike - but she is dangerously unpredictable.
Nightwarden Minthara: If there is a way to turn this design toward slaughter rather than control, she will take it.
Nightwarden Minthara: She is the one who brought me to Moonrise, and into the presence of her so-called god - the Absolute.
Nightwarden Minthara: Now I know that those memories are lies.
Nightwarden Minthara: There was no god. Orin held me down in a cocoon of flesh, while a mind flayer forced a parasite into my brain. And she laughed at my fear.
Nightwarden Minthara: I will find her, I will murder her. And I will smile.
Player: Once she's dead, the cult will need new leadership - perhaps we can take her place.

Abdirak: Greetings, child. I fear your companion could not fully embrace my penance.
Abdirak: But I understand. Pain is something that requires commitment, wouldn't you say?
Player: I couldn't agree more.

Abdirak: I pity them. They've missed out on the true intimacies of pain...
Abdirak: Forgive me, but that look in your eyes - something terrible has happened to you.
Player: I'm trying to resist my drive to do harm, but it's very difficult.
Abdirak: Do not be ashamed, child. What I see in your eyes, in your soul, is only natural.
Abdirak: We've all suffered in these dark times. It is little wonder you bear scars of pain and anguish.
Abdirak: Please let me alleviate this pain.
Player: I know of your penance - my companion has tried it.

Abdirak: Well, perhaps you'd be interested in finishing what they started?
Abdirak: Care to expand your horizons? It will be worth it - you have my word.
Lae'zel: By all means - let us see what his 'skilled hand' might get up to.
Player: Prepare for the coming pain.
Abdirak: Oh, I have something exquisite in mind.
